text:
If the web app name of the URL is written in the wrong case, then the user
session will be created on each request. This will lead to lost session data.

I think that either wrong case should be prohibited or work fully.

I've had severe problems with this.... even though the work around is very
simple :-)

Test case:
Run tomcat on your local computer and check:
http://localhost:8080/eXamples/servlet/SessionExample
creator: david.larsson@systeam.se
cmanolache@yahoo.com
text:
It looks like it works with wrong case only because of security workarounds, 
if we don't do insensitive matching on Windows then security constraints are 
useless. It is not supported - and very difficult to disable. The mapping must 
be case insensitive, but the handler could detect if the file is not 
'identical' with the resource on disk - but that could brake symlinks or 
something else. 

I don't think this is a bug - but if it is, I don't think we should even try 
to fix it, as too much may brake.

creator: david.larsson@systeam.se
text:
Wouldn't it be possible to allow case insensitive web app names? Everything but 
the session seems to work now...

creator: cmanolache@yahoo.com
text:
Sorry, but I think this would be a bad idea. What we should do is report an
error in the first place, but this is difficult and might affect security
checks. I don't want to destabilize the code to support something that should be
supported in the first place.
